content:
Diagnosis:
Metastatic mixed adenocarcinoma-neuroendocrine carcinoma of prostate with choroidal and widespread bone metastases

Previous treatment:
Androgen deprivation therapy from January 2023
Docetaxel 6 cycles completed March 2023
Cabazitaxel 4 cycles April-July 2023
Lu-PSMA 2 cycles August-September 2023

Current status:
Clinical and radiological progression
New onset right eye visual disturbance
PSA rising from 0.8 to 2.1
CGA rising from 45 to 89

Recent investigations:
MRI orbits 12 October 2023 - new right choroidal metastasis 8mm
CT scan 10 October 2023 - progression in bone metastases with new lesions in T4 and L2 vertebrae
Molecular testing confirms AURKA amplification

Current issues:
Right eye visual disturbance
Increasing bone pain requiring oxycodone 40mg bd
Fatigue WHO PS 2

Assessment:
I reviewed [redacted name] today who has developed rapid progression of his castrate-resistant prostate cancer with mixed neuroendocrine features. He has new choroidal metastasis causing visual symptoms and progressive bone disease. Given the molecular profile showing AURKA amplification and aggressive clinical course, we will switch to platinum-based chemotherapy with carboplatin/etoposide. He understands the aims and risks of treatment. He will also require urgent radiotherapy to the right orbit.

Plan:
1. Commence carboplatin AUC 5 D1 and etoposide 100mg/m2 D1-3 q21 days
2. Urgent referral for orbital radiotherapy
3. Continue denosumab and ADT
4. Review in 2 weeks with blood tests
5. Repeat imaging after 2 cycles

primary_cancer.metastases: choroidal metastasis and widespread bone metastases including T4 and L2 vertebrae

cancer_timeline.value: PSA rising from 0.8 to 2.1, CGA rising from 45 to 89
CT shows progression in bone metastases with new lesions in T4 and L2 vertebrae
MRI orbits shows new right choroidal metastasis 8mm

patient_facts.value: Increasing bone pain requiring oxycodone 40mg bd

status_updates.value: Castrate-resistant prostate cancer with mixed neuroendocrine features showing rapid progression with new choroidal metastasis and progressive bone disease. Switching to platinum-based chemotherapy due to molecular profile and aggressive disease course
Clinical and radiological progression with rising PSA and CGA markers
Plan to commence carboplatin AUC 5 D1 and etoposide 100mg/m2 D1-3 q21 days
Review in 2 weeks with blood tests, urgent referral for orbital radiotherapy
